Dengue is endemic in the Indian subcontinent and four serotypes have been co-circulating, with DENV 2 and DENV 3 dominating [ 33]. However, the distribution and dissemination patterns of the different genotypes are not uniform. A study showed that the DENV 3 genotype III (DENV 3-III) was spread from the Indian subcontinent to East Africa first and then from there to Latin America [ 34]. Another study on DENV 2 showed that the cosmopolitan genotype was spread from the Indian subcontinent directly to Latin America [ 14]. In addition to the Indian subcontinent, dengue is also endemic in Brazil. Even in two separate regions of the world where dengue is endemic, the specific evolutionary drivers of a given serotype and genotype may differ.
